CatDescriptText: Mr. Alfred DiOrio, unemployed steelworker, Mingo Junction, W. Va., was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 10, 1959, pg. A1 with question: "How do you think Soviet Premier Khrushchev's visit to the United States affected relations between our country and Russia? Were you or were you not impressed by his visit to Pittsburgh?" answer reads: "A lot of good should come from the visit but it depends on whether or not Khrushchev's words were truthful or just propaganda.  When he first arrived, the people were very skeptical towards him, but when he left, he was more acceptable... Personally, I don't car [sic] for him, but you have to give him credit.  He is a great talker...always lets you know that he things that he is the top dog..."
TitMainTitle: Portrait of Alfred DiOrio, wearing light colored grid patterned shirt and dark checkered jacket, standing in front of Bud Saunders Flower shop, in Jenkins Arcade, Downtown
